meta.title: The Climate Journey
meta.description: A scroll-driven documentary about our climate future

entry.emphasis: there are proven ways to change this scenario.

scale.text: Not all solutions carry the same weight.
scale.followUp: Some act on the surface. Others change the system.

toolkit.title: The Toolkit
toolkit.instruction: Explore the levers that change the system

forests.text: Conserving forests prevents billions of tons of CO₂ every year.
forests.context: Impact comparable to removing over 1.5 billion cars from the roads.

indigenous.text: Where indigenous territories are recognized, the forest remains standing.
indigenous.data: Indigenous lands have significantly lower deforestation rates than neighboring areas.
indigenous.source: Nature Scientific Reports (2023) / FAO / Rainforest Foundation
indigenous.anchor: This is not a climate policy. It's a way of life.

systems.text: The climate crisis doesn't come from technology alone.
systems.followUp: It comes from economic systems based on continuous extraction.
systems.alternative: Other systems organize identity, economy, and well-being without destroying the base that sustains them.

cleanEnergy.text: The energy transition is already underway.
cleanEnergy.data: Today, solar energy is on average 41% cheaper than the cheapest fossil alternative.

efficiency.text: Doing the same thing using less energy is one of the fastest ways to reduce emissions.
efficiency.data: Efficiency can reduce up to 20% of global emissions.

transport.text: Electric vehicles emit much less throughout their entire lifecycle.
transport.data: On average, up to 68% fewer emissions than combustion vehicles.

agriculture.intro: How we use land in Brazil can be part of the problem — or the solution.

agroforestry.title: Agroforestry
agroforestry.text: Agroforestry combines trees, food, and income in the same landscape.
agroforestry.data: These systems can increase total productivity per hectare while sequestering carbon.
agroforestry.evidence: Studies indicate higher total production per area compared to simple monocultures.

ilpf.title: Crop-Livestock-Forest Integration (ILPF)
ilpf.text: Integrated systems recover degraded pastures and produce more without opening new areas.
ilpf.data: In Brazil, ILPF can significantly increase animal stocking rate per hectare and reduce slaughter time.

regenerative.title: Regenerative Pastures
regenerative.text: Regenerative management improves soil, retains water, and reduces methane emissions.
regenerative.followUp: Producing more in already open areas reduces pressure for deforestation.

agriculture.impact: With different land use, Brazil can produce more food, emit less carbon, and keep forests standing.

pattern.text: No single tool solves everything alone.
pattern.followUp: But together, they completely change the system.

brazilCentral.text: Few countries concentrate so much potential for change in so few fronts.
brazilCentral.followUp: That's why Brazil is not peripheral. It's central.

transition.text: Next: what is being promised — and what still needs to be done.

act2.title: The Anatomy of the Problem
act2.subtitle: Where does all this come from?

activities.text: It all starts with human activities.

emissions.text: Each activity releases gases that get trapped in the atmosphere.
emissions.microText: They retain heat. That's what warms the planet.

atmosphere.text: The more gases, the more heat is retained.

global.text: Globally, the main cause is clear:

toggle.brazilText: In Brazil, the story is different.
toggle.brazilFollowUp: Here, deforestation and agriculture share the spotlight.

deforestation.followUp: And the ability to absorb CO₂ disappears.

agriculture.followUp: a gas much more potent than CO₂ in the short term.

systemic.followUp: It's about entire systems of production and land use.

brazilMatters.followUp: Few countries concentrate so much impact in a single factor.

transition.text: Next: What actually changes the game.

arrival.text: In 2024, the planet crossed a threshold that should never have become normal.

timeBegins.ariaLabel: Thermometer and timeline showing temperature progression since 1900

present.mainText: 2024 was the hottest year ever recorded.
present.credibility: Independent measurements from NASA, Copernicus and the World Meteorological Organization.

average.centerText: The global average doesn't tell the whole story.
average.followUp: Some regions of Brazil are already living in a world above 2 °C.

impacts.intro: What does this mean in practice?

extremeHeat.title: More extreme heat days
extremeHeat.description: Heat waves that used to be rare now happen every year.

health.title: More hospitalizations and deaths
health.description: Excessive heat increases risks of dehydration, heart and respiratory problems.

drought.title: Longer and more severe droughts
drought.description: Less water for consumption, agriculture and energy generation.

disasters.title: Climate disasters exploded in Brazil
disasters.description: Since the 1990s, extreme events increased more than 460% and have affected 92% of the country's municipalities.

impacts.closing: These are not projections. This is happening now.

landing.mainText: This is not a future scenario.
landing.subText: This is where we already are.
landing.followUp: What comes next depends on what we do now.

transition.microText: Next: Where does all this come from?

thermometer.ariaLabel: Interactive thermometer showing temperature rise in Brazil
thermometer.narrative: In some regions of Brazil, temperatures have already risen more than 2°C above pre-industrial levels.

timeline.ariaLabel: Timeline showing acceleration of temperature rise
timeline.narrative: Most of this warming happened in just a few decades.

comparison.ariaLabel: Comparison between global and Brazil regional warming
comparison.title: Global Average vs Regional Reality
comparison.narrative: The global average hides regional extremes.

narratives.heading: The Earth is warming
narratives.body: Over the past century, our planet has experienced unprecedented changes in temperature patterns.

narratives.heading: The numbers tell the story
narratives.body: Global temperatures have risen by approximately 1.1°C since pre-industrial times.

narratives.heading: Visible consequences
narratives.body: From melting ice caps to rising sea levels, the effects are becoming increasingly apparent.

narratives.heading: The carbon footprint
narratives.body: Human activities have released billions of tons of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.

narratives.heading: Where emissions come from
narratives.body: Energy production, transportation, and industry are the largest contributors.

narratives.heading: Interconnected systems
narratives.body: Our economic and social systems have evolved around fossil fuel dependency.

narratives.heading: Clean energy transition
narratives.body: Solar, wind, and other renewable sources offer a path to decarbonization.

narratives.heading: Efficiency gains
narratives.body: Smarter buildings, vehicles, and processes can dramatically reduce energy consumption.

narratives.heading: Nature-based solutions
narratives.body: Forests, oceans, and ecosystems play a crucial role in absorbing carbon.

narratives.heading: Global commitments
narratives.body: Nations have pledged to limit warming to 1.5°C through the Paris Agreement.

narratives.heading: Individual and collective action
narratives.body: Every choice matters, from personal habits to policy advocacy.

narratives.heading: A hopeful future
narratives.body: With determination and collaboration, a sustainable future is within reach.
